docs.lead_paragraph: With the Senate facing a potential deadline next week for voting on its health care legislation, interest groups have unveiled a raft of television commercials  most of them arguing against the bill.
docs.abstract: With the Senate facing a potential deadline next week for voting on its health care legislation, interest groups have unveiled a raft of television commercials - most of them arguing against the bill.
docs.snippet: With the Senate facing a potential deadline next week for voting on its health care legislation, interest groups have unveiled a raft of television commercials - most of them arguing against the bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: I've heard many soldiers say they'd rather spend another month in Afghanistan than go through S.R.P., the Soldier Readiness Process. S.R.P. is also used as a verb: to participate in the Soldier Readiness Process - the paperwork, screenings, immunizations, filling out a will, life-insurance, power of attorney and all the stuff you do before you can deploy. Imagine masses of cranky soldiers in crowded waiting rooms.
docs.abstract: War may be hell, but getting ready to deploy is a battle all its own.
docs.snippet: War may be hell, but getting ready to deploy is a battle all its own.

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated | 8:30 p.m. Senate Democratic leaders said Monday that they were prepared to drop a proposed expansion of Medicare and make other changes in sweeping health legislation as they tried to rally their caucus in hopes of passing the bill before Christmas.

headline.main: Democrats Likely to Drop Medicare Expansion

docs.abstract: Senate Democrats said on Monday that they were prepared to abandon a proposal to allow people to begin purchasing coverage through Medicare at age 55.
docs.snippet: Senate Democrats said on Monday that they were prepared to abandon a proposal to allow people to begin purchasing coverage through Medicare at age 55.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and CARL HULSE

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House, pushing back against Republican assertions that President Obama's proposed health care overhaul would drive up health costs, said Monday that the measure being considered in the Senate would ultimately slow the growth of health care spending by 1 percentage point a year.

headline.main: White House Sees Slower Health Spending

docs.abstract: The White House, pushing back against Republican assertions that the proposed health care overhaul would drive up spending, said the Senate's measure would ultimately slow the growth of health care spending by 1 percent a year.
docs.snippet: The White House, pushing back against Republican assertions that the proposed health care overhaul would drive up spending, said the Senate's measure would ultimately slow the growth of health care spending by 1 percent a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: Victor Fuchs, the eminent health economist at Stanford, recently sent me an e-mail message that I thought was worth sharing:
docs.abstract: A Stanford economist suggests that most people do not understand health care, let alone health reform.
docs.snippet: A Stanford economist suggests that most people do not understand health care, let alone health reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline.main: Who's Taking Care of Your Mother?

docs.abstract: Probably another woman, perhaps you. An economist discusses why elder care usually involves women taking care of women.
docs.snippet: Probably another woman, perhaps you. An economist discusses why elder care usually involves women taking care of women.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was fate. Or just bad luck. But pity the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, of Nevada. For months, Mr. Reid kept spinning the political roulette wheel and no matter how many times he tried, the ball kept landing on 60.

headline.main: Is Reid Cursed by the Lucky Number 60?

docs.abstract: For Harry Reid, the theory of having 60 votes on his side in the health care debate may be than blinding him to political realities.
docs.snippet: For Harry Reid, the theory of having 60 votes on his side in the health care debate may be than blinding him to political realities.

docs.lead_paragraph: A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appears in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
docs.abstract: Dropping flat-panel TV prices, tracking down the source of a small phone bill charge and other consumer-focused items from the Times.
docs.snippet: Dropping flat-panel TV prices, tracking down the source of a small phone bill charge and other consumer-focused items from the Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's stimulus redux, and liberal Democrats are not going to be happy about it.

headline.main: Health Fight Echoes the Stimulus Battle

docs.abstract: As Senate centrists seek scale-backs in the health bill, many Democrats see unwelcome parallels to the economic stimulus compromises of last winter.
docs.snippet: As Senate centrists seek scale-backs in the health bill, many Democrats see unwelcome parallels to the economic stimulus compromises of last winter.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. David A. Paterson announced that he would unilaterally withhold $750 million in scheduled payments to schools and local governments, saying that strong action was necessary to protect New York State from insolvency.

headline.main: Paterson Cuts $750 Million in School and Local Aid
